<h2 class="topic-title"><a href="./viewtopic.php?f=3&amp;t=5572">2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h2>
<!-- NOTE: remove the style="display: none" when you want to have the forum description on the topic body -->
<div style="display: none !important;"><ul><li>This has become our largest and most active forum because the physics GRE is just one aspect of getting accepted into a graduate physics program.</li><li>There are applications, personal statements, letters of recommendation, visiting schools, anxiety of waiting for acceptances, deciding between schools, finding out where others are going, etc.</li></ul><br /></div>

																											      	    <h3 class="first"><a href="#p47073">2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																				      <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=47073#p47073"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19465" class="username">DivineHorseCloud</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Sun Jul 06, 2014 10:08 pm </p>



																																							       <div class="content">This is the most useful resource PhysicsGRE has to offer. If you have used this information in the past or are currently using it to help decide upon schools, I highly suggest you help out and post your own profile once you have applied to schools. Future members of this forum will find it very useful! Don't be shy!<br /><br />Copy and paste the template below in your reply to keep the formatting.<br /><br />______________________________________________<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Undergrad Institution</span>[/b]: (School or type of school, such as big state, lib arts, ivy, technical, foreign (what country?)... Overall Reputation in Physics?)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Major(s)</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Minor(s)</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]GPA in Major</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Overall GPA</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Length of Degree</span>[/b]: (Are you graduating after 3, 4, or 5 years?)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Position in Class</span>[/b]: (No numbers needed, but are you top? near top? average? struggling?)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Type of Student</span>[/b]: (Domestic/International, male/female, minority?)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]GRE Scores </span>[/b]: (revised or old version?)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Q</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]V</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]W</span>[/b]:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]P</span>[/b]:<br /><br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]TOEFL Total</span>[/b]: (if applicable, otherwise delete this)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Research Experience</span>[/b]: (At your school or elsewhere? What field? How much time? Any publications (Mth author out of N?) or conference talks etc...)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>[/b]: (Within your school or outside?)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>[/b]: (Such as tutor, TA, SPS officer etc...)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>[/b]:<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Special Bonus Points</span>[/b]: (Such as connections, grad classes, famous recommenders, female or minority status etc...)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>[/b]:<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">[b]Applying to Where</span>[/b]:<br /><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">[u]School</span>[/u] - Department - Research Interest<br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">[u]School</span>[/u] - Department - Research Interest<br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">[u]School</span>[/u] - Department - Research Interest<br />______________________________________________</div>




																																													      </div>

																																													       </div>

																																																																																	   <div class="content"><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution</span>: Big Canadian public school, best known for astronomy<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Physics and mathematics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>: none<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GPA in Major</span>: 3.84 physics, 3.57 mathematics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA</span>: 3.67 undergrad, 3.80 masters <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree</span>: Undergrad 3.5 years, grad 2 years<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Near top<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student</span>: International male<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores </span>: Revised<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q</span>: 167 (95%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">V</span>: 162 (89%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W</span>: 4.0 (54%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P</span>: 910 (86%)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">TOEFL Total</span>: 110<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience</span>: 1 year in theoretical particle cosmology, no publications (most likely won't be submitted in time)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: Dean's list (all undergraduate semesters)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: TA for group theory in physics, departmental assembly member for two years<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points</span>: Graduate coursework in QFT, general relativity, standard model, recommender connections at some schools (UPenn, WUSTL, Tufts, Dartmouth, and a few more I could have missed)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>: Graduated in 3.5 years because of CEGEP in the undergraduate way; GPA on 4.3 scale<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where</span> (all for theoretical particle cosmology):<br /><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">UPenn</span> - Physics and astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 3/18</span> <img class="smilies" /><span style="text-decoration: underline">UChicago</span> - Astronomy and astrophysics <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/9 (goodbye top-10 schools)</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Minnesota-Twin Cities</span> - Physics <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 1/29 $24,440 TA+ $2,500 for moving expenses; ATTENDING!</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: 2/23</span> and <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 4/15</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Dartmouth</span> - Physics and astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 																																																																																																																															    	  <h3 ><a href="#p47361">Re: 2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																																																																																																																						       <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=47361#p47361"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19143" class="username">flobadobadie</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Fri Aug 29, 2014 7:46 pm </p>



																																																																																																																																									        <div class="content"><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution</span>: Cambridge University<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Subject</span>: Physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Class</span>: First/2:1<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree</span>: 4 yrs<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Top half<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student</span>: International male<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores</span> : <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q</span>: 170<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">V</span>: 165<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W</span>: 4.0<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P</span>: 980<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience</span>: One paper published in Physical Review D, one paper published in conference proceedings, both with one other author. 12 months in Particle Phenomenology at Cambridge, 6 months in quantum integrable systems at Surrey University. Wasn't some prof's data collecting lackey. <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: Not any that make sense to AdComms <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: Private tutor<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>: Can hold breath for 2.5 minutes. 																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				  <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=47714#p47714"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19570" class="username">aquirdturtle</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Tue Oct 28, 2014 10:15 am </p>



																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																							   <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Large State school, Ranked ~50 in physics<br />Major(s): Physics<br />Minor(s): Mathematics<br />GPA in Major: 4.00<br />Overall GPA: 4.00<br />Length of Degree: 4<br />Position in Class: At the top (kinda have to be...)<br />Type of Student: Domestic White Male, socioeconomically advantaged <br /><br />GRE Scores (revised, Updated in November):<br />Q: 170 (98%)<br />V: 166 (96%)<br />W: 5 (93%)<br />P: 990 (94%)<br /><br />Research Experience:<br />- Currently in 3rd year of UG research at my home institution in Condensed matter theory. I had a publication in progress (i.e. being written) at the time of applications with myself as first author, but it didn't get submitted for publication until January after deadlines. I presented my work at 1 conference, one small event.<br />- REU in experimental condensed matter physics (Cornell), 1 publication with myself as second author, one conference preceedings.<br />- REU in experimental AMO physics (Michigan), no publications expected, uniquely selected from REU students to present my research at CUR national REU symposium.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: (Within your school or outside?)<br />- Goldwater Honorable Mention<br />- Won a competitive departmental essay prize<br />- Various Honors scholarships<br />- Various departmental scholarships<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs:<br />- Tutored students from an interdisciplinary science class for a semester.<br />- On the leadership team founding an interdisciplinary undergraduate research club.<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: (Such as connections, grad classes, famous recommenders, female or minority status etc...)<br />- Taking 2 grad physics classes now, will take 3 in spring<br />- I'm lucky enough to be able to solicit 4 letters, 1 from UGR at home institution, one from each REU, another from professor I've taken ~4 small classes with, and done a study abroad with.<br />- I take a lot of credits, Almost double the average some semesters, despite having only 1 major &amp; 1 minor.<br />- Took a non-standard interdisciplinary introductory science sequence, instead of the normal &quot;fundamentals of physics&quot; class-type. Also did some other non-physics stuff, like organic chemistry &amp; a nanoscience study abroad (only 2 weeks long).<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter:<br />- I'm not really committed to any field of physics yet, or even experimental Vs. theoretical, I just like all of physics too much  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_rolleyes.gif" alt=":roll:" title="Rolling Eyes" />. Leaning toward experimental AMO. Hope this doesn't count against me. <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_confused.gif" alt=":?" title="Confused" /> <br />- I've played trumpet in at least one music ensemble every semester of undergrad.<br /><br />Applying to Where:<br /><br />All regular physics programs, all AMO physics as my primary interest<br /><br /><span style="color: #408000">Stanford: ACCEPTED! 2/12.</span><br /><span style="color: #800000">MIT: REJECTED. 2/18.</span><br /><span style="color: #800000">Harvard: REJECTED. 3/2.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">Cal-Tech: ACCEPTED! 2/12.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">Berkeley: ACCEPTED! 2/25.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">Chicago: ACCEPTED! 1/30.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">Cornell: ACCEPTED! 2/10.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">U Michigan: ACCEPTED! 1/14.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">Yale: ACCEPTED! 2/26.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">UC Boulder: ACCEPTED! 1/29.</span><br /><span style="color: #408000">U Maryland: ACCEPTED! 2/10.</span><br /><br /><span style="color: #800000">NSF Fellowship: REJECTED, 4/1. E/VG, VG/VG, F/P. I think that the wide disparity of the score here is something of a testament to how much of a shot in the dark these things can be. That last guy must just not have had his morning coffee.</span><br /><span style="color: #800000">NDSEG Fellowship: REJECTED, 4/1. </span><br /><span style="color: #800000">Hertz Fellowship: REJECTED, 1st round </span><br /><br />Reflections: I obviously have nothing to complain about, but in all honesty I was somewhat surprised to not get into Harvard or MIT. I have several theories as to why this happened, but the most probable was that my letters weren't as good as they could have been. In particular, my first REU at Cornell was my first exposure to experimental physics at all, and I probably wasn't particularly impressive a student throughout the summer. If you try something like that, make sure you know what you are doing going in so that you can be as productive as possible. Evidently, if you are coming from a sub-top-20 undergraduate institution, you really, really need every advantage to get into these places. I am also suspicious, particularly with MIT, that the schools were turned off by my lack of firm commitment to AMO physics. They might prefer that students know exactly what they want to do. I'm only speculating of course. Anyway, I'm quite happy with my many offers. Good luck to future applicants!</div>

Another year of CME research on micromechanical exfoliation properties of metal dichalcogenides and the characterization of such materials through optical microscopy and STM. Expected paper by next semester which I will most likely be the first author.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Scholarships within the physics department and Honors (which probably has no bearing whatsoever in the application process...)<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: None really. I tutor my friends in freshman physics often, but I don't do it for pay or anything to consider it a part-time job or &quot;pertinent activity.&quot;<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: Currently taking a graduate mathematical methods course and will be taking graduate courses in solid state physics (second semester; first semester is an undergrad/grad course) and quantum mechanics. Also taking math classes in complex analysis for fun and engineering courses in semiconductor devices. <br /><br />I don't know if this is a bonus point at all, but I'm on a track to graduate in three years. I guess it isn't bad to take graduate courses in your third year of undergrad, no? At the same time though, I basically lost a summer of applying to an REU and one whole year of research at my university :/ Mixed bag, I guess.<br /><br />Although I'm a minority, I have no idea how many &quot;domestic Asian male&quot; applicants apply and what the general statistic is for scores and such for that particular pool. So I have minority status, but once again, I have no idea how I stand up to other domestic Asians or even international Asians if all odds are against me.<br /><br />Lastly, one of my letter writers (whom is also the professor teaching the solid state physics course) did his post-doc at Berkeley, so he has a ton of connections to the Condensed Matter Experimental folks there. Luckily, Berkeley happens to be my top choice <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_biggrin.gif" alt=":D" title="Very Happy" /> <br />My other letter writers will be the professor I did HEP-Ex research for and another professor who I've had for all my courses and labs in for astrophysics.<br /><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Applying to Where:</span><br /><br />I'm applying to CME, sooooo yeah. 																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																						  <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=47973#p47973"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19759" class="username">Ancalimë</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Mon Nov 17, 2014 11:17 pm </p>



																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																									   <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Medium-sized private US research university, top 30 for Physics<br />Major(s): Physics<br />Minor(s): Mathematics<br />GPA in Major: 3.89<br />Overall GPA: 3.95<br />Length of Degree: 4 years<br />Position in Class: Top 10%<br />Type of Student: International white male<br /><br />GRE Scores : revised<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q: 170 (98%)<br />V: 161 (87%)<br />W: 4.5 (80%)<br />P: 990 (94%)</span><br /><br />Research Experience: A little over 12 months at my institution, currently working on a senior thesis in HEP-ex (previously worked in CME and had a Medical Physics internship). No publications.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Departmental &amp; university awards, former Physics Olympiad winner and double medalist at IJSO.<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: Vast experience in teaching as TA + tutoring. I really like teaching!<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: Trained classical singer, Expert-level chess player, club-level table tennis player.<br /> <br />Special Bonus Points: Nope.<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: Learned calculus when I was in 8th grade. Have been doing college-level Physics for almost 10 years now in various contexts.<br /><br />Applying to Where: <span style="text-decoration: underline">All HEP-ex</span> with a secondary interest in CME.<br /><br />Princeton - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/19</span><br />Harvard - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 3/2</span><br />Stanford - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/17</span><br />Yale - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/16</span><br />Columbia - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 3/27</span><br />UMD - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/16</span><br />UCBoulder - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 3/2 - $17.3k/9 months TA + $1k initial &quot;signing bonus&quot;</span><br />UIUC - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 1/30 - $22.2k/11 months TA</span><br />UW Seattle - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/11 - $21.6k/11 months TA + $2.5k initial &quot;signing bonus&quot;</span> <span style="color: #FF0000">DECLINED</span><br /><br />Notes &amp; observations: Grades and test scores are not everything. This is not undergrad anymore, where you have to show the committee that you are a well-rounded individual with a balanced set of skills. Grad school is really the time of your life when you become the best at a VERY SPECIFIC skillset. The top schools will gladly admit people with a ton of research experience and some publications (not necessary, but usually a deciding factor when judging two similar applicants), although some of them have not seen the sunlight in 4 years! I was expecting more positive responses from the elite schools I applied to, not in small part due to my stellar undergraduate record. However, looking back, I should have spent more time trying to do research, if not during the school year, then at least during the summer. Moreover, I am not sure if my letters of recommendation were very strong, a concern I expressed as early as I made an account here. So, to conclude (from importance of item to the overall application):<br /><br />- get good grades in your upper-division Physics courses (especially important if you studied Physics at a renowned university)<br />- Physics GRE. You should absolutely study for this exam. A month should be enough, but some people might find that is not enough. Grab &quot;Conquering the Physics GRE&quot;, easily the best resource on the market.<br />- Have meaningful research experience. I cannot stress this enough. While having publications helps, it is not necessary. On the other hand, you need to show that you have learned techniques which are translatable to graduate school. Drilling holes and melting tubes doesn't count...<br />- Letters of rec, General GRE (don't be an analphabet!  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_mrgreen.gif" alt=":mrgreen:" title="Mr. Green" /> ), overall GPA, personal statement. Don't ever lie!<br />______________________________________________</div>

TA+RA + $4k relocation + tuition + $4.5k travel allowance</span><br />UArizona - Planetary Sciences - <span style="color: #0000FF">Skype interview 1/20</span> - <span style="color: #FF0000">rejected 2/4</span><br />UCDavis - Earth and Planetary Sciences - <span style="color: #0000FF">phone interview 1/27</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">accepted 2/8 - $17.4k/9 mo. RA + tuition + $14k scholarship</span><br />UCSC - Earth &amp; Planetary Sciences - <span style="color: #0000FF">informal email indicating acceptance 2/2</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">accepted 3/9 - $18.7k/9 mo. TA+RA + $12k summer + tuition + $2.5k scholarship</span> <span style="font-weight: bold"><span style="color: #FF8000">WILL ATTEND</span></span><br />UColorado - Astrophysical &amp; Planetary Sciences - <span style="color: #00BF00">accepted 1/30 - $17.4k/9 mo. TA/RA + $11.7k summer RA + tuition - $1k fees + $2k fellowship</span><br />UHawaii - Geology &amp; Geophysics - <span style="color: #0000FF">phone interview 3/4, acceptance indicated</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">accepted 3/10 - One year fellowship $28k; next years RA $2k/ mo. + $7k/mo. of summer ($32k/yr.) + tuition</span><br />UMaryland - Astronomy - <span style="color: #0000FF">waitlisted 2/3 - interview 3/11</span> -  <span style="color: #FF0000">rejected 4/14</span><br /><br /><br />Reflection: If you want to do planetary science, PGRE doesn't matter, as many schools don't even ask for it. It seems my strong letters of recommendation, GPA, GRE, and laboratory research went a long way to getting me accepted, even though I have no publications. My statements were mostly talking about my time in labs and computer experience, in addition to mentioning professors at the school I was applying to as people who researched topics similar to my interests. Many professors at (accepted) schools I visited commented that they loved my computer programming experience, so I'd recommend prospective grads start learning Python and C++. I think my record shows that you can be an upper tier student with almost no professional output yet and still get in if you apply to enough schools.</div>

In 8 years in an industry that prides itself on specialization, I ended up all over the place.</div>

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																		        <div class="content">This will get updated once I get the admission results back! <br />Undergrad Institution: Small LAC (many graduate and get admitted to top colleges for experiment, but idk how to judge reputation). <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">PA in Major</span>G: 3.5ish<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA</span>: 3.5ish<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree:</span> 4<br />Position in Class: cum laude (idk what percent that corresponds to.) Honors in major too. <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student:</span> Domestic <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores</span> : (revised or old version?)<br />Q: 74%<br />V:50%<br />W:56%<br />P: 700 (52%) *this is the score i am submitting, I have taken it multiple times* <br /><br /><br />Research Experience: Hep-th at undergrad , hep-th at a top school. Despite the lack of publications, I think I did well. My advisors were happy and I know they will write my strong recommendation letters. <br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Honors in major, graduated cum laude, a couple of fellowships for summer research. <br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: Tutor, SPS President. <br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: <br /><br />Special Bonus Points: My profs have pretty good connections for hep-th, but I am not applying for it. Soo IDK what to put here. <br /><br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: Grades have been inconsistent. I don't do well on timed exams, but otherwise I have taken many advanced courses and went for breadth. <br /> <br /><br />Applying to Where: For physics, All for CME/CMT...interest in  HEP-th might have been obvious from research experience+I talked about problems I am interested in <br /><br /> <span style="color: #00BF00"> Purdue University - Jan 22 </span><br /><br /> <span style="color: #00BF00"> Ohio State University- Jan 23 </span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">University of California Los Angeles - Feb 27 Rejected via email. Oh well =) </span><br /><br /><span style="color: #FF0000"> UIUC - Late March </span><br /><br /><span style="color: #FF0000"> USC - May (snail mail, I don't know the exact date because I went on vacation)  </span><br /><br /><span style="color: #FF0000"> Penn State - mid March </span><br /><br />*I had other application acceptances, but they were not for physics and some were job applications. The choice was very hard to make between grad school and job, but that's life. Decisions are tough. I hope future applicants will also have a variety of  options to choose from, but in the end you can only pick one.*  <br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold"><span style="color: #0000FF">Disregard this advice if you want to do experiment (below)</span></span><br /><br />If I could have done things differently, I would have signed up for September AND October test.  Physics gre scores matter a lot for theory. If you lurked around this forum, you already know that. However, how much it matters depends on the school you went to. From my experience, it matters a lot if you didn't go to a topish  school for undergrad (in physics). I would have given myself more options if I had a higher pgre score. Obviously grades matter too and they matter the most (compared to pgre), but they look at trends, level of the class etc. <br /><br />I don't want to claim being a bad test taker, because I tend to do well on exams that do not have a time pressure on them. Depending on the subject and my comfort in the material, I would do well even with time pressure. For whatever reason, I effed up on the physics gre. On practice exams I was doing much much better. Soo much better that I was confident going into the exam.... <span style="font-style: italic">sucks</span> SO my advice is to do GREAT on the practice test so you will do GOOD on the real thing. Don't aim for GOOD on practice test or otherwise the real one might just be okay ( like me). <br /><br />Also don't lose confidence in physics if you have a sucky physics gre score (unless if you don't know your physics). I was well prepared for the content of the exam, but who knows maybe something equivalent to stage fright crept in. <br /><br />Publications are a great thing to have if you gpa/pgre are sort of on the mediocre range... Because research experience/recommendation letters matter the most in the end. very strong recommendation letters are a must! So form a good relationship with your research mentors and work hard!<br />It's tough to get publications at a small LAC, but even at other schools it depends on the prof and really good timing. <br /><br /><br />I do not regret applying to the schools I did, in fact, it was a good range in my opinion (if you take into account ALL applications and not just physics).  NEVER just aim too high or too low... aim for places you can thrive in and be happy living in. If getting a post doc and being a faculty matters to you then work hard to get into a school that will take you on that path. For the record, most schools do... but it all depends on you.</div>

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																								     <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Big State School, not sure about rank, but it's solid. Maybe top 50?<br />Major(s): Astronomy-Physics<br />Minor(s):<br />GPA in Major: 3.66<br />Overall GPA: 3.66 (weird coincidence)<br />Length of Degree: 4 years<br />Position in Class: Not sure...near lower top probably<br />Type of Student: Domestic white male<br /><br />GRE Scores : (revised or old version?)<br />Q: 170 (98%)<br />V: 162 (89%)<br />W: 5.0 (93%)<br />P: 990 (94%)...shocked on this. averaged around an 800 on practice tests. Strongly recommend using &quot;Conquering the Physics GRE&quot; to study<br /><br /><br /><br />Research Experience: 2 summers (1 full time, 1 part time), and 2 semesters, for 2 total projects. First was an xray astronomy project that, while valuable, didn't get very far as I lacked computer experience. 2nd project was a much more involved star formation project. Will result in 1 Nth author paper and 1 first author paper (in that order), and I plan on presenting at conferences. No publications/posters at time of application though.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: All at school. Best was a school-wide scholarship I applied for and won. Other than that I was in a Greek Honor Society, got a top 20% of class award, and of course a few Dean's Lists<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: Tutor for ESOL kids in math and science for 2 years. TA for 2 semesters. Lab Assistant for 1 summer. Volunteered at a local observatory for ~30 hours 1 summer<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: Who knows<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: Strong letters, a few grad classes (even though I'm pretty sure they don't care about that)<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: <br /><br />Applying to Where (All Observational Astronomy):<br /><br />Ohio State: <span style="color: #FFBF00">WAITLISTED via email 1/4 - Withdrew application</span><br />Caltech: <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/17</span><br />Princeton: <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/6</span><br />Columbia: <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email to check website 2/26 </span><br />Yale: <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email to check website 2/23 </span><br />UT-Austin:  <span style="color: #00FF00">Interview request via email 1/20 - Skype Interview 1/23 - Accepted via email 1/29! $30K from TAship and fellowships </span><br />U Colorado-Boulder:  <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/13</span><br />Penn St: <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted via phone call 1/24 - Received fellowship totaling 33k for first year</span> <br />U Maryland: <span style="color: #40FF00">Interview request via email 2/13 - Skype Interview 2/16 - Accepted 4/13 - 27K TA +  5K fellowship </span><span style="color: #4000FF">WILL ATTEND</span><br />Johns Hopkins: <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 4/10</span><br />U Virginia: <span style="color: #FFBF00">WAITLISTED via email 2/24 - Withdrew Application 3/29</span><br />U Chicago: <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email to check website 2/9</span><br />U Michigan : <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 3/13 </span><br /><br />I had strong test scores but not a great research profile, so I applied to many top 30 schools figuring that if I have a ~10% chance of getting into one, then by applying to many my odds would be a lot better. Fortunately, it worked. I got a healthy amount of rejections, but my acceptances gave me some leeway to choose where I thought I would be happiest. While UT-Austin is perhaps a more highly regarded program, UMD just happens to be a better fit for me. Hopefully my profile will help future applicants.<br /><br />ADVICE: If you want to maximize your chances of getting into school, start research early. But it's okay to have a balanced life and not research until 3rd year because you can still get into school. If you are domestic like me, it might be smart to focus your applications towards upper level public schools, as I fared a lot better with them.</div>

													<div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Jesuit Liberal Arts - Considered top masters level university in midwest for multiple years<br />Major(s): Mathematics, Physics<br />Minor(s): n/a<br />GPA in Major: 3.94(math) 3.87 (physics)<br />Overall GPA:3.78<br />Length of Degree: 4 years<br />Position in Class: top physics major, unsure and don't care about overall class... lot of premeds with 4.0 bio degrees and no problem solving skills<br /><br />Grad Institution (masters): Same Jesuit Liberal Arts University<br />Major: Physics<br />GPA: 4.00<br />Length of Degree: 2 years (thesis track)<br /><br />Type of Student: Domestic White Male (sad)<br /><br />GRE Scores : (revised or old version?)<br />Q: 168<br />V: 167 <br />W: 4.5<br />P: 820<br /><br /><br />Research Experience:<br />4 years molecular biophys<br />2 years AMO<br />1 REU in dark (figured out the prof is totally uninterested in physics research... still brags about being a theorist)<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: <br />Got an REU<br />Was a Goldwater applicant for my school (told by advisors it wasn't worth mentioning because i didn't win or get honorable mention)<br />Misc. awards for being best student and researcher in both math and physics<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs:<br />Tutored physics 6 years<br />tutored calc/linear/DEs 4 years<br />TA'd a lot of upper division math courses<br />TA for physics department as grad student<br />Good amount of paid research<br />SPS Physics Club secretary <br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help:<br /><br />Jazz Guitarist<br /><br />Special Bonus Points:<br />My grad advisor worked at JQI as a postdoc. Met a several people from Maryland (though not exactly in fields I'm intending to PhD in)) at DAMOP in Madison.<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter:<br />Programming for some while, all self taught. Includes C/C++, FPGA board programming, Labview, ROOT<br /><br />I have switched fields a few times... kinda worried about that looking poorly. I just like physics, but in todays age that seems like a death sentence... :/<br /><br />Applying to Where: all for quantum computing except for UCSF which is for two-body problem considerations. Listed in no particular order of preference (although cali is kinda where i want to go)<br /><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">UCSF - Biophysics - Nanobots - REJECTED 1/12 Form Email, Ce le vie... San Fran...</span> <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_sad.gif" alt=":(" title="Sad" /><br /><span style="color: #FF00Asked if I wanted to be on the waitlisted by email 2/12/15, I said yes </span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">Yale - applied physics - QC - pending</span><br /><span style=ing a gap year or something because its geographic location is a significant detractor for my significant other (&quot;allergic&quot; to the cold).</div>

																																																				    	  <h3 ><a href="#p48660">Re: 2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																																											       <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48660#p48660"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</sppaper under review 2nd author (There's only been one week in my entire two years where our system was working well enough to take data :'( )<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: A few. Mostly for being a female and doing well.<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: TA for two years.<br /><br />Speciolor: #FF0000"> Rejected</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Santa Barbara - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 2/3 - TA 26,748</span> <span style="color: #000080">Declined. I really wanted to go here but I don't want to sacrifice my standard of living. Plus I have a boyfriend coming with and it's a bit harder for him to find a job around this area.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">MIT - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/18 I wasn't going to apply here initially since there wasn't anyone I was excited about working with, but my boyfriend wanted to move to Boston. Gotta tell him the bad news.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Cornell - AEP</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 2/12 - Unknown Source 24,658 for nine months.</span> <span style="color: #000080">Declined. Too depressing. Great opportunity, but I'll get caught in a rut if I go here.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Columbia - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #FF0000"> Rejected.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Rutgers - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 2/6 TA + Excellence + Torrey Fellowship ~29K for 10 months + 1700-4000 if TA/GSR Summer</span> <span style="color: #000080">Declined.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Maryland College Park - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 2/10, Offer Letter to come -&gt; Offer letter came:</span><br />For people who want info about what kind of pay is here, 22.7k for first year, 25.2k for second year, 29k once advanced to candidacy. Living around here is kind of expensive. Commuters have to move their cars when big games happen. I received an RA offer and two fellowships which amount to 5k/year for five years. There's also national labs around which students frequently work in.<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Stonybrook - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #000080">Decided against applying once I got admitted to another school (I <span style="font-style: italic">really</span> don't want to live on long island)</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Johns Hopkins - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 1/22 - TA 25k for 9 months. Research over summer is an additional 8333. Possibly more funding after Open House in Feb.</span> <span style="color: #000080">Declined.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Boulder - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 2/18 - TA 17.4k for 9 months. RA full year should be around ~25k. 6k signing bonus.</span> <span style="color: #000080">Declined. A bit sad because I like CO.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">San Diego - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Recommended for Admission 1/23 - Physics Excellence Award + Summer Research Fellowship. Received offer letter 2/21. Wow that took awhile.<br />TA: 18,538 + Excellence: 14,000 over one year + Summer Fellowship: 8,000 = 40,538 for the first year. But it looks like it goes down to somewhere around 25.5k as a 50% GSR appointment. You can do 100% GSR appointments during the summer (makes it ~31k), although I don't know how common that is.</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Washington - Physics</span> - <span style="color: #00BF00">Accepted 1/14 - TAship + 5000 -&gt; Distributed as 1956/month + 2500 by 9/30 </span> <span style="color: #000080">Declined 2/4. I hope someone gets in and can attend visiting weekend!</span><br /><br /><br />Some thoughts:<br /><br />Ultimately, I think going somewhere you're going to be happy is really important <span style="font-style: italic">so long as it doesn't hurt you in the long run.</span> You're going to graduate school for the next five years of your life. This isn't something you just force yourself through to get past it. You need to be happy and enjoy what you're doing so you can succeed, even if that means not going to the highest ranked school you got accepted to. Focus on putting yourself in an environment where you will succeed. At the same time, have an idea with what you want to do after grad school and look at job placement rates, who's coming to career fairs, and linkedin data. Make sure you aren't wasting your time. Being able to learn enough programming to land a shitty job is going to be worth more than completing a PhD at some no name university unless you obtain usable skills in the process.</div>

																																																																																																									        <h3 ><a href="#p48661">Re: 2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																																																																																																     <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48661#p48661"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19925" class="username">PhysicsIsCool</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Wed Jan 14, 2015 9:30 pm </p>



																																																																																																																			      <div class="content"><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution:</span> Small, private, liberal arts university<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s):</span> Physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s):</span> Chemistry<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GPA in Major:</span> 4.0<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA:</span> 3.93<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree:</span> 4 years<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class:</span> Top or near the top (in a small program though)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student:</span> Domestic white female<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores:</span><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q:</span> 167 (94%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">V:</span> 157 (74%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W:</span> 3.5 (38%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P:</span> 880 (Sept. test, 83%); 780 (Oct. test, 67%)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience:</span> Summer 2013 REU at UIUC in the physics department--experimental condensed matter physics research (superconductivity). Continued working at UIUC after my summer internship until April 2014. Summer 2014 REU at Yale University in the applied physics department--materials science research (ferroelectrics and complex oxides); presented research at the 2014 Leadership Alliance National Symposium. Now working at my home institution since August--AMO research.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions:</span> Physics scholarship from my home institution, 2013-14. SPIE Optics and Photonics Education Scholarship, 2014-15. Goldwater scholar, 2014-15.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs:</span> TA since May of my sophomore year (teacher's assistant for various labs including first-year mechanics and electricity and magnetism; scientific imaging; sound, music, and hearing; and intermediate experimental methods). Physics tutor since my sophomore year (for first-year calculus- and algebra-based physics courses).<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points:</span> One well-known recommender.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter:</span> Founding member of the student chapter of SPIE at my university; secretary and then co-president of the Society of Physics Students at my university; member of APS.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where:</span><br /><br />(research interest for all: condensed matter/materials physics)<br /><br /><span style="color: #FF0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Harvard</span> - Applied Physics - Rejected 03/03/15</span><br /><span style="color: #40BF00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Cornell</span> - Applied Physics - Accepted 02/12/15 - TA or RA (24.7k per 9 months)</span><br /><span style="color: #40BF00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">UIUC</span> - Physics - Accepted 01/25 - 22.2k/11 months</span><br /><span style="color: #40BF00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">CU Boulder</span> - Physics - Accepted 02/09 - TA or RA (17.4k or 20.5k per 9 months), 6k signing bonus - Increased 6k to 10k signing bonus with the possibility of receiving one during my second year as well</span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Stanford</span> - Applied Physics - Rejected 02/02/15 &lt;/3</span><br /><span style="color: #40BF00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">UC Berkeley</span> - Physics - Accepted 02/20/15 - Offered first-year TA + summer research $29.9k, $1k for moving expenses - offered $1.5k extra per year during NSF Fellowship, also likely that research advisor will &quot;top off&quot; the stipend - will attend!</span><br /><span style="color: #40BF00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">UC Davis</span> - Materials Science - Accepted 01/17/15 - at least $27.5k/year</span><br /><span style="color: #40BF00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Northwestern</span> - Materials Science - Accepted! 02/11/15 - 28.9k first-year fellowship, 1.5k for moving expenses </span><br /><br /><span style="color: #40BF00">NSF Graduate Research Fellowship awarded 04/01/15 - $34k/yr for 3 years</span></div>

 var googletag = googletag || {};
 googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
 (function() {
   var gads = document.createElement('script');
   gads.async = true;
   var useSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
   gads.src = (useSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') +
       '//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js';
   var node = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
   node.parentNode.insertBefore(gads, node);
 })();

</script>

 // GPT slots
 var gptAdSlots = [];
 googletag.cmd.push(function() {

   // Define a size mapping object. The first parameter to addSize is
   // a viewport size, while the second is a list of allowed ad sizes.
   var mapping = googletag.sizeMapping().

   // Accepts both common mobile banner formats
   addSize([320, 200], [[320, 50], [320, 100]]).

   // Landscape tablet
   addSize([800, 200], [728, 90]).build();

   // Define the GPT slot
   gptAdSlots[0] = googletag.defineSlot('/51894415/pgre_bottom_responsive', [320, 50], 'ad-slot').
       defineSizeMapping(mapping).
       addService(googletag.pubads());
   googletag.pubads().setTargeting("test","responsive");

   // Start ad fetching
   googletag.enableServices();
 });
</script>
